I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Government of New 
Zealand, both to the Republic of Vanuatu for the Interisland Shipping Support Project. The 
report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) to be cofinanced by the Government 
of New Zealand for the Establishment of the Maritime Safety Administration, and if the Board 
approves the proposed loan and administration of grant, I, acting under the authority delegated 
to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The proposed project will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of interisland shipping 
services through provision of an integrated package of assistance.2 The project comprises two 
major components: (i) infrastructure investments in the capital of Port Vila and five outer islands, 
and (ii) shipping support and coordination schemes to catalyze the provision of services to 
remote noncommercial destinations using an output-based aid approach. The project will be 
complemented  by  associated  TA  to  improve  sector  governance  through  institutional 
strengthening and legal and regulatory reforms, and by project management services. The 
project and TA activities will reinforce each other so that services to remote communities 
increase to self-sustaining levels.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Vanuatu depends on water transport as its population of about 240,000 is spread over 
an archipelago of some 60 populated islands. However, a number of sector constraints hold 
back economic growth and service delivery in Vanuatu. Inadequate infrastructure limits cargo 
and passenger movement. Unfavorable geography and poorly functioning markets make some 
services commercially unviable. Outdated and fragmented sector governance further impedes 
service provision. These factors restrict the development of productive rural livelihoods focused 
on agriculture exports, but rural and national development can be significantly enhanced by 
improving water transport.3 
 
4.  The government's Priorities and Action Agenda, 2006–2015 and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy, 2010–2014 aim to reduce critical constraints to rural 
accessibility by improving transport infrastructure and services.4 The project will address the 
infrastructure and market constraints, while associated TA will address the governance issues.  
 
5.  Infrastructure. Inadequate wharves and jetties restrict the ability of vessels to call at 
destinations in all weather conditions. Restricted access causes increased waiting times and 
costs, and in some cases prevents vessels from reaching rural areas altogether. Poor facilities 
also cause difficulties in safe loading of passengers and loss of goods because of the need to 
transfer them by small craft to and from ships standing at sea while unable to anchor.

2 
6.  Improved infrastructure is needed to increase efficiency, allow more frequent services, 
reduce hazards, and facilitate growth. A new interisland shipping terminal in Port Vila, which is 
the hub of the network, will eliminate a binding constraint on shipping services caused by an 
acute and worsening shortage of berths. New and rehabilitated rural jetties will improve reliable 
access to disconnected communities and facilitate commodity exports. The enhanced safety 
brought about by the project is particularly important for people needing health care, children 
traveling for education, and women who usually bear the responsibility to assist them.  
 
7.  Service provision. Vanuatu has a sufficient domestic fleet but services are not provided 
to some remote locations due to market failure and a consequent mismatch between supply and 
demand. Shipping services are not provided due to uncertain demand in rural areas, while 
demand is not communicated effectively due to the uncertainty of service provision. Interisland 
water transport is therefore infrequent and unreliable. 
 
8.  The shipping support and coordination schemes will correct this mismatch through better 
information and competitively tendered short-term subsidies. Rural producers will be more likely 
to prepare their produce for market once voyages are guaranteed, while vessel operators will be 
more willing to undertake voyages when cargo and passenger volumes are known. Subsidies 
are justified to help correct this market failure and trigger positive externalities. Support for 
noncommercial destinations will catalyze rural production and increase reliability, helping to 
develop a sustainable market for services and commercially viable private sector operators.  
 
9.  Improved  infrastructure  and  more  reliable  services  will  lead  to  greater  efficiencies 
throughout the water transport sector. The direct beneficiaries will include people in the poorest 
parts of the country, although the entire country is expected to benefit from the project as the 
economy largely depends on the water transport sector. Direct benefits of the project will include 
more frequent and more reliable shipping services at lower cost as private sector operators take 
advantage of new opportunities. Induced benefits will include increased agricultural production 
and better terms of trade for remote communities. The project will have important additional 
benefits for women, who have unique needs and responsibilities for supporting family health 
care, schooling, and income generation. By facilitating access to markets and social services, 
and  enabling  rural  populations  to  market  their  produce  and  derive  income  from  natural 
resources, the project will spur economic growth and reduce poverty.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The  impact  will  be  improved  access  to  socioeconomic  opportunities  by  people  in 
Vanuatu, particularly in the national capital of Port Vila and the provinces of Malampa, Penama, 
Sanma,  Shefa,  and  Tafea.  The  outcome  will  be  reliable,  safe,  and  adequately  frequent 
interisland shipping services provided by private sector operators.  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
11.  Outputs will include (i) improved water transport infrastructure in the capital and rural 
areas, (ii) shipping support and coordination schemes, and (iii) project management services for 
efficient and effective project implementation. The first two outputs are described in paras. 12-
14. The third output is described under implementation arrangements in para. 19. These outputs 
will be complemented by TA to enhance capacity for sector governance and maritime safety 
oversight described in paras. 23–26.

3 
1.  Infrastructure 
 
12.  Port Vila has insufficient domestic berths and faces the impending loss of nearly all 
remaining berths, with potentially severe consequences for national commerce. Therefore, a 
new interisland shipping terminal will be built in Port Vila, with sufficient berthing capacity to 
simultaneously handle the mix of conventional vessels and landing craft in the Vanuatu fleet. To 
improve rural access, four new outer island jetties will be constructed5 and three existing outer 
island jetties will be rehabilitated.6 All sites will have ancillary infrastructure to cater to the transit 
of  passengers  (including  market  shelters  and  separate  facilities  for  women,  men,  and  the 
disabled) and storage for cargo transshipment.  
 
13.  All infrastructure will be designed and built to international standards and will have an 
expected design life of 50 years. Designs will adopt a low-maintenance strategy in recognition of 
the risks of cyclones and earthquakes, as well as the limited capacity for maintenance on outer 
islands. Special measures will remove barriers to access by women and the disabled, and will 
ensure adaptation to the effects of climate change. The government will ensure that its recurrent 
budget for maintenance of the new and rehabilitated facilities is allocated and executed to 
preserve the assets and avoid deterioration. 
 
2.  Shipping Support and Coordination 
 
14.  Two schemes will be established. A shipping support scheme will provide subsidies for a 
fixed number of voyages at designated frequencies on otherwise commercially unviable routes.7 
The scheme will be based on a least-cost tender process for services to be provided by private 
sector  operators.  Under  an  output-based  approach,  subsidies  will  be  tied  to  performance, 
including vessel suitability, franchise areas and routes, voyage locations and frequency, and 
substantiation  of  voyages.  Vessels  will  be  required  to  meet  safety  standards  and  provide 
facilities to reduce barriers to use by women. A shipping coordination scheme will appoint 
people  in  each  province  to  promote  and  aggregate  demand,  and  communicate  needs  for 
voyages to private sector vessel operators. Demand for services will be differentiated by gender 
and location, and services will be required to facilitate access by women. Subsidies required will 
decline over time as routes become commercially viable. The support program is scheduled to 
be implemented over 5 years and will be regularly reviewed during implementation.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economic  Management  (MFEM)  will  be  the  executing 
agency and the Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Utilities (MIPU) will be the implementing 
agency.  The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  within  the  Public  Works  Department  will  be 
responsible for day-to-day implementation. It will be supplemented by project implementation 
assistance  fully  integrated  in  MIPU’s  management  structure  consisting  of  national  and 
international consultants and MIPU counterpart staff. Given the MIPU's limited technical staff 
resources,  a  consulting  firm  will  be  retained  for  these  services.  At  the  request  of  the 
government,  ADB  will  select  the  consultants  and  the  recruitment  will  be  conducted  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
20.  Civil works for a number of procurement packages will be procured through international 
competitive  bidding  and  national  competitive  bidding.  All  civil  works  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).

22.  Stakeholders in project implementation include MFEM; MIPU and its departments of 
maritime affairs, ports and harbors, and public works; other government departments concerned

6 
with rural development; transport services users, including passengers and freight shippers; the 
private sector; the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade (NZMFAT); ADB; and 
other development partners. The government will form a project steering committee to oversee 
and  monitor  project  implementation,  including  policy  guidance  and  coordination,  technical 
design  and  tendering,  progress  reports,  and  audited  accounts.13  A  partner  harmonization 
framework will guide coordination between ADB and NZMFAT. 
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
23.  Because of inadequate governance and regulation, the government is unable to ensure 
the safe operation of vessels. MIPU nominally oversees sector governance, with safety and 
security responsibilities divided between the Department of Maritime Affairs and the Department 
of Ports and Harbours. Additional responsibilities for economic regulation and international 
matters are assigned to the Ministry of Trade, Tourism, Commerce and Industry; the Ministry of 
Internal Affairs, and MFEM. Consequently, the sector is characterized by fragmentation, a lack 
of coordination, and inconsistency between legal and regulatory instruments. There is also a 
gap in personnel and capacity, causing noncompliance with national and international standards 
for safety and security. 
 
24.  Governance reforms and capacity development will support MIPU in restructuring its 
departments and strengthening its management, operations, and regulatory role. Activities will 
include  (i)  updating  legislation  and  providing  for  adequate  delegation  of  responsibility  and 
authority to ensure compliance with safety regulations, (ii) drafting regulations to implement the 
new legislation, (iii) institutional restructuring in MIPU and its departments, and (iv) training and 
capacity development for staff assigned to new roles. An institutional development plan will be 
developed to increase the participation of, and benefits to, women in the sector. The output will 
be  improved  institutional  capacity  for  maritime  safety  compliance  including  vessel  registry, 
inspection, survey, licensing of seafarers, and administration of ports and harbors.  
 
25.  A TA grant for the Establishment of the Maritime Safety Administration will be provided 
to reform sector governance. The TA is estimated to cost $1.50 million, of which $1.00 million 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Government of New Zealand and administered by ADB. 
The balance of $0.50 million will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will contribute $0.45 million for workshops, training, 
and  surveys  plus  $48,000  equivalent  in  kind  for  a  total  TA  budget  of  about  $2.0  million. 
Implementation arrangements and terms of reference are provided separately.14  
 
26.  To complement the project, ADB's Private Sector Development Initiative,15 cofinanced 
by the Government of Australia, may provide TA in parallel to assess the potential for a public–
private  partnership  to  develop  a  slipway  to  repair  domestic  vessels.  The  government  is 
exploring options to invite private sector investment to build, own, and operate a facility.  
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
27.  Due diligence was performed in the areas of technical design; economic and financial 
feasibility; poverty, social and gender issues; governance matters; safeguards; and risks and 
mitigating  measures.  Analyses  were  based  on  extensive  consultations  with  potential

14 Technical Assistance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

beneficiaries in rural and urban areas, and with the government, civil society, nongovernment 
organizations, other development partners, and the private sector.  
 
A.  Technical 
 
28.  For potential civil works, analyses covered site selection, preliminary engineering, and 
cost estimates. The technical assessment showed that a new domestic terminal in Port Vila is 
urgently required because of an acute and worsening shortage of berthing capacity and growing 
demand for passenger and cargo handling. The assessment also identified outer island sites 
with suitable locations and sufficient projected demand to justify provision of four new jetties and 
rehabilitation of three existing jetties. Given their remote locations, the outer island jetties will be 
based on standard designs that use materials and techniques (such as stainless steel and 
precast  concrete)  that  assure  initial  quality  and  minimize  maintenance.  Final  engineering 
designs  will  consider  the  potential  effects  of  climate  change  and  incorporate  necessary 
measures for adaptation. 
 
29.  For the shipping support and coordination schemes, services were found to require 
support on two broad routes to the farthest northern and southern islands. The hardships 
caused by infrequent and unreliable services make support for these locations socially desirable 
but commercially unviable because of the distances and limited demand. Analyses covered 
demand  and  supply  projections,  operational  requirements,  and  potential  private  sector 
participation for the proposed shipping support scheme. Projections show that a temporary 
least-cost subsidy would catalyze the market for services and lead to sustainability.  
 
30.  To determine the necessary institutional reforms, analyses examined (i) the structure 
and staffing of the relevant government ministries, departments, and agencies; (ii) existing 
legislation and regulation; and (iii) capacity for public administration. A sequential package of 
reforms  including  restructuring  and  new  legislation  was  designed  to  complement  the 
infrastructure and service support schemes in order to improve the viability of the sector.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
31.  Economic benefits from civil works and service support include induced agricultural 
development,  lower  cargo  loss  and  spoilage,  and  easier  access  to  markets  and  services. 
Benefits from the maritime safety component include lower risk of accidents and better sector 
governance. Economic rates of return on civil works are 16%–30% for new construction, 15%–
224% for rehabilitation, and about 36% for the shipping support scheme. All analyses were 
subjected to sensitivity testing and results were found to be robust in cases of higher costs and 
lower benefits. While components have been analyzed separately, the complementary nature of 
the design means that the economic benefits from implementation of the overall project will 
likely be greater than the sum of the parts.16  
  
32.  Financial  analyses  of  project  components  were  also  conducted.  The  government 
imposes modest charges for use of the facilities in Port Vila but not elsewhere, and none of 
these are expected to run on a commercial basis. Accordingly, the financial rate of return on civil 
works is negative, which is acceptable for public facilities, particularly with high economic rates 
of return. For the shipping support scheme, the financial analysis was based on the estimated 
costs and revenues of an operator using a standard design vessel to provide services on a 
                                                 
16 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
typical route. The financial analysis shows that the required subsidies are small and should 
decline once regular services are established on the routes and economic activity increases.  
 
C.  Governance 
 
33.  Analyses  covered  existing  and  proposed  legislation,  regulations,  and  institutional 
structures for sector planning and administration. A reform program is required and can be 
effectively supported by TA. Vanuatu has a track record of successful reforms, and government 
support for a package of legal and institutional reforms as proposed is strong.  
 
34.  A financial management assessment of MFEM, as the executing agency, and MIPU, as 
the  implementing  agency  established  that  their  policies  and  procedures  were  clear, 
unambiguous,  and  focused  on  control  and  accounting  for  revenue  and  expenditure. 
Procurement  capacity  was  also  assessed.  Since  MFEM  and  MIPU  have  considerable 
experience  in  implementing  external  assistance,  lessons  from  past  projects  have  been 
incorporated into the project design. Capacity development provided through TA will strengthen 
the capacity of MFEM and MIPU for financial management and procurement. The TA will focus 
on project-related expenditures and revenue collection, and on preparing and evaluating bidding 
documents.   
 
35.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government,  including  MFEM  and  MIPU.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
36.  Analyses included an initial poverty and social assessment of the overall project. The 
affordability of transport services was also analyzed to inform the design of the shipping support 
scheme. Data disaggregated by gender and location were collected during project preparation 
consultations,  as  reported  in  the  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy.17  Those 
consulted were almost universally in favor of the project, perceived very few negative impacts, 
and confirmed the expected positive social impacts. Negative impacts, including the potential for 
HIV/AIDS and labor issues, were determined to be minor. Proactive strategies to increase the 
participation of, and benefits to, women were identified for implementation, including setting 
employment  targets,  reducing  barriers  to  services,  and  providing  institutional  support.  The 
project is classified as contributing to effective gender mainstreaming, and a gender action plan 
was prepared to promote equal access and opportunities for women.18 
 
E.  Safeguards 
37.  Potential impacts on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples 
were assessed in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). Civil works as 
proposed  will  not  result  in  any  significant  adverse  environmental  impact,  and  all  potential 
environmental impacts can be adequately mitigated and monitored. An initial environmental 
examination incorporating an environmental management and monitoring plan was prepared for 
each  of  the  sites.19  The  government’s  assessment  procedure  is  compatible  with  ADB’s

environmental  impact  assessment  requirements.  The  project  is  classified  as  environment 
category B. 
 
38.  The  project  is  not  expected  to  require  involuntary  resettlement  or  involuntary  land 
acquisition, as nearly all works will be at the same locations as existing facilities and new works 
will be carried out at sites where the minimal land required has been documented to be owned 
by the government. Minor voluntary land acquisition may be required at one or two sites. If land 
acquisition  is  required,  the  government  will  inform  ADB  and  prepare  a  resettlement  plan 
according to relevant laws and regulations. A resettlement framework has been prepared.20 The 
project is classified as resettlement category C. 
 
39.  Native  Melanesians,  who  comprise  the  vast  majority  of  the  population,  are  the 
indigenous people of Vanuatu. The project is not expected to have a negative impact on them. 
The project is classified as indigenous peoples category C. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
40.  Major risks and proposed mitigating measures proposed are summarized in Table 4.21  
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Technical  Implementation  will  follow  the  project  design  with  respect  to  prescribed 
engineering  design  standards  and  the  recommendation  to  appoint  an 
“Engineer” as defined by FIDIC to oversee the final design and construction 
quality of infrastructure works. 
Financial  The project management unit will adopt a conservative approach with respect 
to cost estimates and required resources, and will promote a competitive 
tendering process with the assistance of the international consultant. TA will 
support improvements in financial management. 
Procurement delays  An international consultant during implementation will support the executing 
agency in the preparation of bidding documents and the evaluation of bids. 
Project management  The project management unit is staffed with qualified personnel and supported 
through institutional strengthening and capacity development. Implementation 
assistance will support construction supervision, contract management, 
financial management, safeguard monitoring, and reporting.  The implementing 
agency will be trained in project performance monitoring and disbursements. 
Institutional reforms and  Development partners and the executing and implementing agencies will 
sector restructuring  collaborate and cooperate through the TA component, which involves regular 
consultations, review missions, and reporting on progress. 
Operation and  Through institutional strengthening and capacity building, the implementing 
maintenance  agency will improve the collection of revenue, which will be allocated for 
operation and maintenance. The implementing agency will undergo training to 
improve its abilities in project and asset management to increase infrastructure 
sustainability. 
FIDIC = International Federation of Consulting Engineers, TA = technical assistance.  
Source:  Asian Development Bank.

21  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
41.  The  government,  MFEM,  and  MIPU  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents.  
  
42.  The government, MFEM, and MIPU have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the loan agreement.  
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
43.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR6,708,000 to the Republic of 
Vanuatu for the Interisland Shipping Support Project, from ADB's Special Funds 
resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the 
grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a 
grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board; and 
 
(ii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$12,600,000 to the Republic of Vanuatu for the Interisland Shipping Support 
Project, to be provided by the Government of New Zealand. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
 
4 November 2011
